questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with poor wound healing, recurring infections, and delayed bone growth. Physical examination reveals keratosis pilaris and follicular hyperkeratosis. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Vitamin A: Correct Answer. The clinical presentation suggests vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A plays a crucial role in immune function, epithelial tissue maintenance, bone growth, and wound healing. The symptoms of keratosis pilaris, delayed bone growth, and recurring infections are classic manifestations of vitamin A deficiency, known as xerophthalmia.
  • • Option A. Vitamin A:
  • • Key clinical features of Vitamin A deficiency include:
  • • Key clinical features of Vitamin A deficiency include:
  • • Impaired wound healing : Due to reduced epithelial cell regeneration Recurring infections : Compromised immune system function Delayed bone growth : Vitamin A's role in osteoblast and osteoclast activity Skin manifestations : Keratosis pilaris, follicular hyperkeratosis Night blindness : Early sign of vitamin A deficiency
  • • Impaired wound healing : Due to reduced epithelial cell regeneration
  • • Impaired wound healing
  • • Recurring infections : Compromised immune system function
  • • Recurring infections
  • • Delayed bone growth : Vitamin A's role in osteoblast and osteoclast activity
  • • Delayed bone growth
  • • Skin manifestations : Keratosis pilaris, follicular hyperkeratosis
  • • Skin manifestations
  • • Night blindness : Early sign of vitamin A deficiency
  • • Night blindness
  • • The treatment involves vitamin A supplementation to restore immune function, epithelial tissue integrity, and support proper growth and development.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Vitamin D: Deficiency typically presents with rickets, bone deformities, and calcium metabolism issues. While important for bone health, it does not fully explain the comprehensive symptoms described in this case.
  • • Option B. Vitamin D:
  • • Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and usually manifests with neurological symptoms, hemolytic anemia, and muscle weakness. It does not account for the specific clinical picture presented.
  • • Option C. Vitamin E:
  • • Option D. Vitamin K: Primarily involved in blood clotting and bone metabolism. The symptoms described go beyond the typical manifestations of vitamin K deficiency.
  • • Option D. Vitamin K:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency presents with complex systemic implications, affecting immune function, epithelial tissue maintenance, bone growth, and wound healing processes.
  • ➤ Key Metabolic Insights:
  • ➤ Key Metabolic Insights:
  • ➤ Vitamin A is critical for cellular differentiation and immune function Deficiency impacts multiple physiological systems Supplementation can reverse many of the clinical manifestations Plays a crucial role in maintaining epithelial tissue integrity
  • ➤ Vitamin A is critical for cellular differentiation and immune function
  • ➤ Deficiency impacts multiple physiological systems
  • ➤ Supplementation can reverse many of the clinical manifestations
  • ➤ Plays a crucial role in maintaining epithelial tissue integrity
  • ➤ Ref: Advanced Pediatric Nutrition and Metabolism Textbooks
  • ➤ Ref: Advanced Pediatric Nutrition and Metabolism Textbooks

questions.text: A lactating mother presents with severe fatigue, brittle nails, and restless legs syndrome. Her blood work reveals increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and decreased serum ferritin. Her diet history reveals excessive tea consumption with meals. Which deficiency best explains these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Iron deficiency is the correct answer. The presentation shows classic features:
  • • Increased TIBC (compensatory mechanism) Decreased ferritin (depleted iron stores) Symptoms of iron deficiency: Fatigue from anemia Brittle nails (koilonychia) Restless legs syndrome Risk factors: Lactation (increased iron demands) Tea with meals (tannins inhibit iron absorption)
  • • Increased TIBC (compensatory mechanism)
  • • Decreased ferritin (depleted iron stores)
  • • Symptoms of iron deficiency: Fatigue from anemia Brittle nails (koilonychia) Restless legs syndrome
  • • Fatigue from anemia Brittle nails (koilonychia) Restless legs syndrome
  • • Fatigue from anemia
  • • Brittle nails (koilonychia)
  • • Restless legs syndrome
  • • Risk factors: Lactation (increased iron demands) Tea with meals (tannins inhibit iron absorption)
  • • Lactation (increased iron demands) Tea with meals (tannins inhibit iron absorption)
  • • Lactation (increased iron demands)
  • • Tea with meals (tannins inhibit iron absorption)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Zinc deficiency: While it can cause growth problems and immune dysfunction, zinc deficiency doesn't affect TIBC or cause anemia-related symptoms.
  • • Option B. Zinc deficiency:
  • • Option C. Vitamin B12 deficiency: B12 deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, but TIBC is typically decreased, not increased.
  • • Option C. Vitamin B12 deficiency:
  • • Option D. Folate deficiency: Causes megaloblastic anemia but doesn't affect TIBC or cause restless legs syndrome.
  • • Option D. Folate deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency diagnostic markers: Increased TIBC Decreased ferritin Low serum iron Clinical manifestations: Fatigue and weakness Koilonychia Restless legs syndrome Pica Risk factors: Pregnancy/lactation Dietary factors (tea, calcium) Blood loss Treatment considerations: Iron supplementation Dietary modification Addressing underlying cause
  • ➤ Iron deficiency diagnostic markers: Increased TIBC Decreased ferritin Low serum iron
  • ➤ Increased TIBC Decreased ferritin Low serum iron
  • ➤ Increased TIBC
  • ➤ Decreased ferritin
  • ➤ Low serum iron
  • ➤ Clinical manifestations: Fatigue and weakness Koilonychia Restless legs syndrome Pica
  • ➤ Fatigue and weakness Koilonychia Restless legs syndrome Pica
  • ➤ Fatigue and weakness
  • ➤ Koilonychia
  • ➤ Restless legs syndrome
  • ➤ Pica
  • ➤ Risk factors: Pregnancy/lactation Dietary factors (tea, calcium) Blood loss
  • ➤ Pregnancy/lactation Dietary factors (tea, calcium) Blood loss
  • ➤ Pregnancy/lactation
  • ➤ Dietary factors (tea, calcium)
  • ➤ Blood loss
  • ➤ Treatment considerations: Iron supplementation Dietary modification Addressing underlying cause
  • ➤ Iron supplementation Dietary modification Addressing underlying cause
  • ➤ Iron supplementation
  • ➤ Dietary modification
  • ➤ Addressing underlying cause

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glycogen storage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A low insulin-glucagon ratio stimulates the mobilization of energy stores by promoting glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis, while it inhibits glycogen storage.

  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

questions.text: Defect of enzyme tyrosine transaminase (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 2 tyrosinemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder characterized by the body's inability to effectively break down the amino acid tyrosine. There are three types of tyrosinemia, each associated with a specific enzyme deficiency:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type I tyrosinemia : This type is associated with a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH), not tyrosine transaminase.
  • • Option A. Type I tyrosinemia
  • • Option C. Alkaptonuria : This condition involves a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, not tyrosine transaminase.
  • • Option C. Alkaptonuria
  • • Option D. Type III tyrosinemia : This type involves a deficiency in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD), not tyrosine transaminase.
  • • Option D. Type III tyrosinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 2 tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme t yrosine t ransaminase and is also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome or Oculocutaneous syndrome.

  • ➤ t

questions.text: Patient with high triglycerides esterified with long chain fatty acid (LCFA) presents with fatigue and biopsy of muscle shows fat vacuoles. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. Deficiency in carnitine leads to the accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids in muscle tissues, causing fatigue and exercise intolerance

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 123

  • ➤ Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase ( G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.

questions.text: Which enzyme serves as the rate-limiting step in bile acid synthesis from cholesterol, and is inhibited by excess bile acids through negative feedback? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7-alpha hydroxylase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 7-alpha hydroxylase is the correct answer. It is the rate-limiting enzyme in bile acid synthesis because:
  • • Catalyzes the first committed step in bile acid synthesis Subject to feedback inhibition by bile acids Regulated by cholesterol levels Expression controlled by nuclear receptors
  • • Catalyzes the first committed step in bile acid synthesis
  • • Subject to feedback inhibition by bile acids
  • • Regulated by cholesterol levels
  • • Expression controlled by nuclear receptors
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. HMG CoA reductase: While this is the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis, it doesn't directly control bile acid synthesis. It's regulated by cholesterol levels and statins.
  • • Option A. HMG CoA reductase:
  • • Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I: This enzyme controls fatty acid entry into mitochondria for β-oxidation. It's not involved in bile acid synthesis.
  • • Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I:
  • • Option D. Carnitine acyltransferase II: Located in the inner mitochondrial membrane, this enzyme is involved in fatty acid metabolism but not bile acid synthesis.
  • • Option D. Carnitine acyltransferase II:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand rate-limiting enzymes in different pathways:
  • ➤ Bile acid synthesis: 7-alpha hydroxylase (CYP7A1) Regulated by bile acids and nuclear receptors First committed step Key regulatory features: Feedback inhibition Transcriptional control Response to cholesterol levels Clinical relevance: Bile acid metabolism disorders Cholestatic liver disease Gallstone formation
  • ➤ Bile acid synthesis: 7-alpha hydroxylase (CYP7A1) Regulated by bile acids and nuclear receptors First committed step
  • ➤ 7-alpha hydroxylase (CYP7A1) Regulated by bile acids and nuclear receptors First committed step
  • ➤ 7-alpha hydroxylase (CYP7A1)
  • ➤ Regulated by bile acids and nuclear receptors
  • ➤ First committed step
  • ➤ Key regulatory features: Feedback inhibition Transcriptional control Response to cholesterol levels
  • ➤ Feedback inhibition Transcriptional control Response to cholesterol levels
  • ➤ Feedback inhibition
  • ➤ Transcriptional control
  • ➤ Response to cholesterol levels
  • ➤ Clinical relevance: Bile acid metabolism disorders Cholestatic liver disease Gallstone formation
  • ➤ Bile acid metabolism disorders Cholestatic liver disease Gallstone formation
  • ➤ Bile acid metabolism disorders
  • ➤ Cholestatic liver disease
  • ➤ Gallstone formation

questions.text: Decreased transferrin saturation is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the concept of transferrin saturation and how it relates to various conditions related to iron metabolism. Decreased transferrin saturation is typically seen in conditions of iron deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, where there is insufficient iron to fully saturate transferrin.

questions.text: Ammonia is neutralized and transported from brain tissues through which of the following metabolic pathways? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glutamate dehydrogenase reaction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Glutamate dehydrogenase reaction: Correct Answer. This enzyme plays a critical role in ammonia metabolism by catalyzing the reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate. In brain tissues, the glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) reaction is crucial for ammonia detoxification by directly converting glutamate to α-ketoglutarate while releasing ammonia, which can then be processed by astrocytes through the glutamine synthetase pathway.
  • • Option A. Glutamate dehydrogenase reaction:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Alanine transaminase cycle: While alanine transaminase is important in amino acid metabolism, it is not the primary mechanism for ammonia neutralization in brain tissues. This pathway is more associated with muscle-liver ammonia transport and does not directly address brain-specific ammonia management.
  • • Option B. Alanine transaminase cycle:
  • • Option C. Ornithine transcarbamylase pathway: This is a key enzyme in the urea cycle, but it operates primarily in the liver. In brain tissues, the direct neutralization of ammonia occurs through different mechanisms, making this option less relevant to brain-specific ammonia metabolism.
  • • Option C. Ornithine transcarbamylase pathway:
  • • Option D. Urea cycle intermediate formation: The urea cycle is predominantly a liver-based process for final ammonia detoxification. Brain tissues employ alternative mechanisms for initial ammonia management, primarily through glutamate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase reactions.
  • • Option D. Urea cycle intermediate formation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ammonia Metabolism in Brain Tissues
  • ➤ Ammonia Metabolism in Brain Tissues
  • ➤ Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) is a key enzyme in brain ammonia metabolism The enzyme catalyzes reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate Brain tissues have specialized mechanisms for initial ammonia neutralization The GDH reaction is part of a complex neurometabolic process for managing nitrogen-containing compounds
  • ➤ Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) is a key enzyme in brain ammonia metabolism
  • ➤ The enzyme catalyzes reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate
  • ➤ Brain tissues have specialized mechanisms for initial ammonia neutralization
  • ➤ The GDH reaction is part of a complex neurometabolic process for managing nitrogen-containing compounds
  • ➤ Key Metabolic Insights:
  • ➤ Key Metabolic Insights:
  • ➤ Brain ammonia management differs from liver-based urea cycle Glutamate dehydrogenase plays a crucial role in initial ammonia detoxification The reaction involves direct conversion of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate Astrocytes are primary cells responsible for ammonia neutralization in neural tissues
  • ➤ Brain ammonia management differs from liver-based urea cycle
  • ➤ Glutamate dehydrogenase plays a crucial role in initial ammonia detoxification
  • ➤ The reaction involves direct conversion of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate
  • ➤ Astrocytes are primary cells responsible for ammonia neutralization in neural tissues
  • ➤ Ref: Advanced Neurobiochemistry Texts on Nitrogen Metabolism
  • ➤ Ref: Advanced Neurobiochemistry Texts on Nitrogen Metabolism

questions.text: A newborn presents with seizures and developmental delay. Genetic testing reveals a mutation affecting glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier. Which glucose transporter deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GLUT 1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GLUT 1 is the correct answer. GLUT 1 deficiency syndrome occurs due to impaired glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) because:
  • • GLUT 1 is the primary glucose transporter in the BBB Brain cells depend on continuous glucose supply Deficiency leads to cerebral energy crisis Results in seizures, developmental delay, and neurological symptoms
  • • GLUT 1 is the primary glucose transporter in the BBB
  • • Brain cells depend on continuous glucose supply
  • • Deficiency leads to cerebral energy crisis
  • • Results in seizures, developmental delay, and neurological symptoms
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. GLUT 2: While important for glucose sensing in pancreas and liver, GLUT 2 deficiency primarily affects glucose homeostasis and insulin secretion, not brain glucose transport.
  • • Option B. GLUT 2:
  • • Option C. GLUT 3: Although present in neurons, GLUT 3 isn't the primary transporter at the BBB. Its deficiency wouldn't cause the initial glucose transport problem across BBB.
  • • Option C. GLUT 3:
  • • Option D. GLUT 4: GLUT 4 is insulin-dependent and primarily functions in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissue. It's not involved in brain glucose transport.
  • • Option D. GLUT 4:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand:
  • ➤ GLUT 1's critical role in: Blood-brain barrier glucose transport Basal glucose uptake Brain energy metabolism Clinical features of GLUT 1 deficiency: Early-onset seizures Developmental delay Movement disorders Treatment with ketogenic diet Tissue-specific functions of GLUTs: BBB (GLUT 1) Insulin-responsive tissues (GLUT 4) Liver/pancreas (GLUT 2) Neurons (GLUT 3)
  • ➤ GLUT 1's critical role in: Blood-brain barrier glucose transport Basal glucose uptake Brain energy metabolism
  • ➤ Blood-brain barrier glucose transport Basal glucose uptake Brain energy metabolism
  • ➤ Blood-brain barrier glucose transport
  • ➤ Basal glucose uptake
  • ➤ Brain energy metabolism
  • ➤ Clinical features of GLUT 1 deficiency: Early-onset seizures Developmental delay Movement disorders Treatment with ketogenic diet
  • ➤ Early-onset seizures Developmental delay Movement disorders Treatment with ketogenic diet
  • ➤ Early-onset seizures
  • ➤ Developmental delay
  • ➤ Movement disorders
  • ➤ Treatment with ketogenic diet
  • ➤ Tissue-specific functions of GLUTs: BBB (GLUT 1) Insulin-responsive tissues (GLUT 4) Liver/pancreas (GLUT 2) Neurons (GLUT 3)
  • ➤ BBB (GLUT 1) Insulin-responsive tissues (GLUT 4) Liver/pancreas (GLUT 2) Neurons (GLUT 3)
  • ➤ BBB (GLUT 1)
  • ➤ Insulin-responsive tissues (GLUT 4)
  • ➤ Liver/pancreas (GLUT 2)
  • ➤ Neurons (GLUT 3)

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Causes of pellagra
  • ➤ Causes of pellagra
  • ➤ Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis. Malabsorption Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  • ➤ Maize and Jowar in Diet:
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome:
  • ➤ Malabsorption
  • ➤ Malabsorption
  • ➤ Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Drugs like Isoniazid

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence GATCTAC. What is the base sequence of RNA product?( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GUAGAUC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The base sequence of RNA formed is exactly same as non-template strand which in this case is 5’ GTAGATC 3’. We have to just replace the T with U to get the RNA sequence. So RNA sequence is: 5’ GUAGAUC 3’
  • • The base sequence of RNA formed is exactly same as non-template strand which in this case is 5’ GTAGATC 3’.
  • • We have to just replace the T with U to get the RNA sequence. So RNA sequence is: 5’ GUAGAUC 3’

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The complementary base pairing rules are:
  • ➤ The complementary base pairing rules are:
  • ➤ Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA. Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A). Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G). Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).
  • ➤ Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • ➤ Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • ➤ Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • ➤ Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).
  • ➤ The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are necessary for purine ring formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glycine, aspartate, glutamine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Purine ring formation requires the amino acids glycine, aspartate, and glutamine.
  • • These three amino acids provide crucial nitrogen and carbon atoms that are incorporated into the purine ring structure during its biosynthesis. Specifically, glycine contributes carbon and nitrogen, aspartate contributes a nitrogen, and glutamine provides another nitrogen atom. This combination is essential for the complex two-ring structure of purines.
  • • In contrast, pyrimidine rings, which have a single-ring structure, require only aspartate and glutamine for their formation.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Glycine, aspartate, valine: Valine is not involved in purine synthesis. Valine is a branched-chain amino acid used primarily in protein synthesis and energy production.
  • • Option A. Glycine, aspartate, valine:
  • • Option C. Glycine, aspartate, glutamate: Glutamate does not participate in purine ring formation. Glutamate is primarily involved in amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis.
  • • Option C. Glycine, aspartate, glutamate:
  • • Option D. D. Glycine, aspartate, alanine: Alanine is not involved in purine ring formation. It is a non-essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis and glucose metabolism, but it does not contribute to the nitrogen or carbon framework of purines.
  • • Option D. D. Glycine, aspartate, alanine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Important one liner
  • ➤ Important one liner

  • ➤ AA for Purines - Aspartate, Glutamine, Glycine
  • ➤ AA for Pyrimidines - Aspartate, Glutamine
  • ➤ Sources of N & C of Urea - CO2, Ammonia, Aspartate

  • ➤ Molecule linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Fumarate

questions.text: Melanin is synthesized from which of the following amino acid? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tyrosine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Correct Answer. Tyrosine, an amino acid, is the primary precursor for melanin synthesis. The process starts with the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA (dihydroxyphenylalanine) by the enzyme tyrosinase, followed by several steps leading to the formation of melanin. This pathway takes place in melanocytes, specialized cells found in the skin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor to serotonin and melatonin, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of melanin. Tryptophan's metabolic pathway is distinct from the pathway leading to melanin production.
  • • Option A. Tryptophan:
  • • Option C. Phenylalanine: Incorrect, but with a caveat. While phenylalanine itself is not directly used in melanin synthesis, it is important to note that phenylalanine can be converted into tyrosine in the body. Therefore, phenylalanine can be considered an indirect precursor to melanin. However, in the context of direct involvement in melanin synthesis, tyrosine is the correct answer.
  • • Option C. Phenylalanine:
  • • Option D. Histidine: Histidine is another amino acid, but it is not involved in melanin synthesis. Instead, histidine plays roles in protein synthesis and the formation of histamine, a compound involved in immune responses.
  • • Option D. Histidine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melanin is synthesized from tyrosine by following pathway.
  • ➤ Melanin
  • ➤ tyrosine
  • ➤ Uses of tyrosine:
  • ➤ Uses of tyrosine:
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 103
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 103

questions.text: In a patient with Wilson's disease, which of the following is decreased in urine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3-methylhistidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration is an inherited autosomal recessive condition.
  • ➤ Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration
  • ➤ autosomal recessive
  • ➤ The basic defect is a mutation in a gene encoding a copper binding ATPase in cells, which is required for excretion of copper from cells. So, copper is not excreted through bile, and hence copper toxicity . Increased copper content in hepatocyte inhibits the incorporation of copper to apo-ceruloplasmin. So ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased . Clinical Features Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis . Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms. Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring. Treatment consists of a diet containing low copper and injection of D-penicillamine , which excretes copper through urine. Since zinc decreases copper absorption , zinc is useful in therapy. Amino acids are excreted in the urine in either conjugated (mostly) or in free form. The amount of conjugated amino acids in urine is far more than free form in Wilson’s disease. Methyl Histidine largely exists in free form and does not increase in amount on hydrolysis of acids in urine, hence the urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are low in patients with Wilson disease.
  • ➤ The basic defect is a mutation in a gene encoding a copper binding ATPase in cells, which is required for excretion of copper from cells. So, copper is not excreted through bile, and hence copper toxicity .
  • ➤ basic defect
  • ➤ copper binding ATPase
  • ➤ copper toxicity
  • ➤ Increased copper content in hepatocyte inhibits the incorporation of copper to apo-ceruloplasmin. So ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased .
  • ➤ ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased
  • ➤ Clinical Features Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis . Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms. Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • ➤ Clinical Features
  • ➤ Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis . Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms. Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • ➤ Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis .
  • ➤ hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis
  • ➤ Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ basal ganglia
  • ➤ lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • ➤ Treatment consists of a diet containing low copper and injection of D-penicillamine , which excretes copper through urine. Since zinc decreases copper absorption , zinc is useful in therapy.
  • ➤ a diet containing low copper
  • ➤ injection of D-penicillamine
  • ➤ zinc decreases copper absorption
  • ➤ Amino acids are excreted in the urine in either conjugated (mostly) or in free form. The amount of conjugated amino acids in urine is far more than free form in Wilson’s disease. Methyl Histidine largely exists in free form and does not increase in amount on hydrolysis of acids in urine, hence the urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are low in patients with Wilson disease.
  • ➤ urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are low in patients with Wilson disease.

questions.text: An Autopsy was conducted on a male with history of drowning. However, no water was found in his lungs, and he was determined to have experienced ‘dry drowning’. What is the cause of death: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Laryngospasm

questions.text: What does the term "corpus delicti" refer to in legal contexts? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Essence of the offense

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • he term "corpus delicti" is a Latin phrase that translates to "body of the crime." It signifies the fundamental facts proving that a crime has been committed. The concept ensures that there must be evidence that a crime has occurred before someone can be convicted for committing the crime. This includes proving that a specific injury or loss resulted from a criminal act.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Deceased body: Incorrect. "Corpus delicti" does not mean a dead body. It refers to the essential evidence that a crime has occurred.
  • • Option A. Deceased body:
  • • Option C. Judicial inquiry: Incorrect. A judicial inquiry is a formal investigation conducted by a judge or judicial panel, which is not related to the concept of proving that a crime has taken place.
  • • Option C. Judicial inquiry:
  • • Option D. Police investigation: Incorrect. A police investigation refers to the process of investigating a crime by law enforcement authorities, not to the legal principle of establishing that a crime has occurred.
  • • Option D. Police investigation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Corpus delicti" refers to the principle that there must be proof of a crime having occurred before someone can be legally convicted of the crime.

questions.text: True regarding CF (Cystic Fibrosis): ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic fluid

options.label: B
options.text: Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

options.label: D
options.text: Chloride secretion is increased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

questions.correct_answer: B. Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In sweat glands, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride reabsorption, resulting in increased chloride secretion in sweat. Therefore, individuals with CF have elevated levels of chloride in their sweat, which is a diagnostic feature of the condition.
  • • In the pancreas, the impaired CFTR function leads to decreased chloride secretion into pancreatic fluid. This results in the production of thick, sticky mucus in the pancreatic ducts, leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The pancreas is unable to release digestive enzymes properly into the small intestine, affecting the digestion of food.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. CFTR is a chloride channel that regulates the movement of chloride ions across cell membranes. In individuals with cystic fibrosis, the function of CFTR is impaired.

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched? Oxygen: Simple Diffusion Glucose: facilitated diffusion and Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport Na: Secondary Active transport

options.label: B
options.text: If a and c are correct

options.label: C
options.text: If a, b and c are correct

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.correct_answer: D. a, b, c, & d are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.
  • • Option A.
  • • Oxygen: Simple Diffusion:
  • • Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion and Na-dependent: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.
  • • Option B.
  • • Glucose: facilitated diffusion and Na-dependent:
  • • Option C. Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:
  • • Option C.
  • • Calcium: Active transport:
  • • Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.
  • • Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  • • Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.
  • • Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium is transported using the Na+-K+ ATPase pump, which is a type of secondary active transport. This pump uses energy from ATP to move sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell, maintaining the necessary gradients for cellular functions.
  • • Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Dinesh Puri 3 rd ed/pg-639

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Non-Homologous End joining

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CRISPR-Cas9 mediated gene repair primarily occurs through Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), an error-prone repair process that ligates broken DNA ends together, often resulting in small insertions or deletions at the repair site.

questions.text: Which toxin can cause acute liver failure and hematuria? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Amanita phylloides

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amanita phylloides, also known as the "death cap" mushroom, contains toxins that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria. The mushroom contains amatoxins, which are responsible for the severe liver damage, and can also affect the kidneys, leading to renal damage and hematuria. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option. A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that can cause respiratory depression and constipation, but it is not typically associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.
  • • Option. A. Morphine:
  • • Option. B. Ketamine: Ketamine is an anesthetic that can cause dissociative effects and hallucinations, but it is not known to cause acute liver failure and hematuria.
  • • Option. B. Ketamine:
  • • Option. C. Belladonna: Atropa Belladonna, also known as deadly nightshade, contains anticholinergic compounds that can cause symptoms such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia. However, it is not associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.
  • • Option. C. Belladonna:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Amanita phylloides, or the "death cap" mushroom, is a toxin that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria due to the presence of amatoxins. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning

questions.text: According to MTP Act, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure requires opinion from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cannot be done

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act in India, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure cannot be legally performed. The MTP Act allows termination of pregnancy due to contraceptive failure only up to 20 weeks of gestation.
  • • For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, MTP is permitted only in certain aggravated conditions, such as:
  • • Rape Minors Disabled women Congenital anomalies Widowhood
  • • Rape
  • • Minors
  • • Disabled women
  • • Congenital anomalies
  • • Widowhood
  • • Contraceptive failure is not included in the list of aggravated conditions for which MTP is allowed between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option. A. 2 doctors: This would be the requirement for MTP between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation in the case of aggravated conditions, but not for contraceptive failure.
  • • Option. A. 2 doctors:
  • • Option. B. 1 doctor: This is the requirement for MTP up to 20 weeks of gestation, but not for the given scenario of 22 weeks due to contraceptive failure.
  • • Option. B. 1 doctor:
  • • Option. C. Medical board: A medical board's opinion is required for MTP beyond 24 weeks of gestation, and only in cases of congenital anomalies.
  • • Option. C. Medical board:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following carbohydrates has the most significant impact on insulin secretion: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option C. Galactose: Correct Answer. Galactose has a unique metabolic pathway that leads to a more pronounced insulin response compared to other monosaccharides. Unlike fructose, which is primarily metabolized in the liver, galactose is quickly converted to glucose-1-phosphate in the liver and then enters glycolysis, triggering a more significant insulin secretion mechanism.
  • • Option C. Galactose:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fructose: Fructose has a minimal direct impact on insulin secretion. It is primarily metabolized in the liver through fructolysis, with minimal stimulation of insulin release. The liver converts fructose to glucose and glycogen, but the process does not directly trigger robust insulin secretion.
  • • Option A. Fructose:
  • • Option B. Glucose: While glucose is the primary stimulus for insulin secretion, its effect is more standard and predictable. Glucose directly stimulates pancreatic beta cells to release insulin through ATP-dependent potassium channel closure and calcium influx. However, the insulin response is less nuanced compared to galactose.
  • • Option B. Glucose:
  • • Option D. Mannose: Mannose has a minimal impact on insulin secretion. It is rarely found in significant quantities in diet and is quickly converted to fructose-6-phosphate in the liver, with negligible direct insulin stimulation.
  • • Option D. Mannose:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulin Secretion and Carbohydrate Metabolism
  • ➤ Insulin Secretion and Carbohydrate Metabolism
  • ➤ Galactose represents a unique carbohydrate with a distinct metabolic pathway that can trigger a more complex insulin response. The conversion of galactose to glucose-1-phosphate involves specific enzymes (galactokinase, galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase) that create a more nuanced metabolic process. Unlike other monosaccharides, galactose's metabolism involves multiple steps that can influence insulin secretion mechanism. Galactose is primarily derived from lactose breakdown and plays a crucial role in glycolipid and glycoprotein synthesis.
  • ➤ Galactose represents a unique carbohydrate with a distinct metabolic pathway that can trigger a more complex insulin response.
  • ➤ The conversion of galactose to glucose-1-phosphate involves specific enzymes (galactokinase, galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase) that create a more nuanced metabolic process.
  • ➤ Unlike other monosaccharides, galactose's metabolism involves multiple steps that can influence insulin secretion mechanism.
  • ➤ Galactose is primarily derived from lactose breakdown and plays a crucial role in glycolipid and glycoprotein synthesis.
  • ➤ Key Metabolic Insights:
  • ➤ Key Metabolic Insights:
  • ➤ Galactose conversion to glucose-1-phosphate occurs through a unique enzymatic pathway The metabolic intermediate stages of galactose can trigger more complex hormonal responses Galactose metabolism involves more enzymatic steps compared to direct glucose metabolism
  • ➤ Galactose conversion to glucose-1-phosphate occurs through a unique enzymatic pathway
  • ➤ The metabolic intermediate stages of galactose can trigger more complex hormonal responses
  • ➤ Galactose metabolism involves more enzymatic steps compared to direct glucose metabolism
  • ➤ Ref: Advanced Biochemistry Textbooks on Carbohydrate Metabolism
  • ➤ Ref: Advanced Biochemistry Textbooks on Carbohydrate Metabolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration
  • ➤ Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement.

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glutamine replaced by asparagine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Conservative replacements, such as replacing glutamine with asparagine, typically do not affect the protein's function because the substituted amino acids have similar properties. Radical replacements, involving amino acids with different properties, are more likely to impact protein function.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ PM findings of hanging in the Neck
  • ➤ PM findings of hanging in the Neck
  • ➤ Petechiae-Tardieu spot La facies sympathique Salivary dribbling Ligature mark Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening Thyroid cartilage Hyoid bone fracture
  • ➤ Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • ➤ La facies sympathique
  • ➤ La facies sympathique
  • ➤ Salivary dribbling
  • ➤ Ligature mark
  • ➤ Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • ➤ Thyroid cartilage
  • ➤ Hyoid bone fracture

questions.text: If a woman is undergoing MTP after 24 weeks of gestation due to congenital anomaly in the fetus , whose presence is not required for authorization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lawyer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MTP after 24 weeks for congenital anomalies, the medical board's authorization is required and comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist. A lawyer’s presence is not required for this authorization process.

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3
  • • Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3
  • • Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine . Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.
  • • Rothera's test:
  • • purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine
  • • Other tests
  • • Other tests
  • • Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.
  • • Test 1: Benedict’s test:
  • • Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars.
  • • The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.
  • • But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.
  • • Test 2: S hows the heat coagulation test . The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.
  • • Test 2:
  • • S
  • • hows the heat coagulation test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Suggillation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post Mortem Staining (PMS)
  • ➤ Post Mortem Staining (PMS)
  • ➤ It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin. Other names of PMS are: Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.
  • ➤ It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • ➤ Other names of PMS are: Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death
  • ➤ Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death
  • ➤ Hypostasis
  • ➤ livor mortis
  • ➤ Vibices
  • ➤ Suggillation
  • ➤ Postmortem Lividity
  • ➤ Cadaveric lividity
  • ➤ Darkening of death
  • ➤ It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Protein folding

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.
